title: Recognizing prototypes from natural and dynamic sources of facial variation: The role of identity and continuity.
abstractText:
If shown some variations on an image of a face, people often later say that they saw the prototype image, from which the variations were derived, with more confidence than those variations they had actually seen.  This is termed the prototype effect (PE) in face recognition and is thought to reflect the way we extract information about the identity of the face. 

One idea is that we combine all experiences with a person's face into an average, or prototype, representation.  However there is no solid evidence linking the perception of identity to the PE, so the primary aim of our research is therefore to test whether the key factor in producing a PE is the observer's belief that different images belong to the same person. 

We shall do this in three distinct ways:

  • by varying the similarity between pairs of photos, and asking about perceived identity
  • by using a novel morphing 3D image, where one person changes subtly into another
  • by using a 'change blindness' approach, where some observers fail to notice that the person in a video has in fact changed. 

We predict that facial variations thought to be the same person will give a bigger PE.
findingsText:
Our change-blindness study produced our predicted effect. We created a video showing a theft, where the identity of the thief changed half way through. Participants watched the video, then attempted to identify people seen in it (which might include the victim) in a serial lineup. This lineup included photographs of both actors who played the thief and an average of their images. People who failed to notice the change of actor were significantly more likely to pick the average image than the originals, while those who did notice were more likely to pick the originals.

Other work still in progress. The implication of the change blindness study is that a witness to a crime who fails to realise that there is more than one perpetrator might form a combined memory and therefore be even less reliable than usual at subsequent identification.
